Dear ELEANOR LOUISE MARQUIS:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
2/27/2023-3/3/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly K. Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
PA 116 722.120(10)(3) Confidentiality
A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care
and shall report to the department, when requested,
the facts the department requires with reference to the
children upon forms furnished by the department.
Except as otherwise provided in this subsection and
subsection (4), records regarding children and facts
compiled about children and their parents and relatives
are confidential and disclosure of this information shall
be properly safeguarded by the child care organization,
the department, and any other entity in possession of
the information
1 of 3 special evaluation reports reviewed contained documentation of CPS
allegations and involvement with the family.
2

CPA Rule 400.12213 Record Management
(1) An agency shall do all of the following with respect
to maintenance of required records:
(b) Keep each record in a uniform fashion.
9 of 11 open youth case files reviewed contained documents that were uploaded
to the case record within 2 weeks of the inspection despite having been
completed at timeframes up to 11 months prior to the upload. Additionally, two
cases contained multiple documents that were signed and dated by youth in
which no corresponding case contacts were present.
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
(3) The training specified in subrule (2)(a)and (b) of this
rule shall address all of the following areas:
2 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained documentation that foster
parents were utilizing theatrical films as the majority of their training hours. The
training documentation completed did not document that required training topics
were covered by the films.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing
the placement of a child in the home.
(b) Documentation that the foster parent is willing to
accept the foster child.
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the
evaluation is acceptable.
(d) A copy of the current reevaluation with written
endorsement by the borrowing agency that the
evaluation is acceptable.
(e) A list of all children currently placed in the home.
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement
signed by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
3

(h) A copy of the current children’s foster home license
application and children’s foster home licensing
transaction record documents from the certifying
agency.
(i) A copy of all special evaluations completed during
the last 2 years.
1 of 3 borrowed foster home files reviewed contained documentation that all of
the requirements of the borrowed bed rule were obtained/completed after the
youth was placed. This citation included subsections a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 2/24/2021, CAP Approved 3/25/2021
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster family,
including information about siblings who do not reside
in the foster home.
1 of 8 files of youth in foster care placements contained documentation that the
required information was not provided to the caregiver timely. This violation
includes subsections a, b, c, d, e, f, g, and h.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 2/24/2021, CAP Approved 3/25/2021
4

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
1 of 11 open youth case files reviewed contained 1 updated service plan that was
not completed timely. (1 of 26 updated service plans reviewed.)
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth’s place of residence.
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is
complying with the terms of the contract required by R
400.12510, continues to reside in a safe and
acceptable environment, and is managing
expenditures.
1 of 3 files of youth in Independent Living Placement reviewed did not contain
documentation of monthly face to face contacts in the youth's residence or
monthly compliance with the IL contracts for 4 separate months. This violation
includes subsections a & b.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the
youth and the social service worker. The contract shall
be reviewed and updated at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
1 of 3 files of youth in Independent Living Placement reviewed did not contain IL
contracts that were updated every 90 days.

FOM 722-06H CASE CONTACTS
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have
been found to produce positive outcomes for children in
foster care. A quality visit is defined as one in which the
caseworker: • Can meet with each child individually,
without the presence of other individuals, to give the
child an opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss
the current placement. • Views the child's bedroom and
sleeping arrangements. • Verifies safe sleep
environments and practices for infants under 12
months. • Assesses each child’s educational, medical,
dental, mental health and other needs and takes
appropriate action or offers services in response to the
identified needs of each child. • Shows interest in the
child to build and establish rapport. • Shares and
explains the case plan, including the plan for parenting
time, visits with siblings and other relatives, and the
child's permanency plan, in a developmentally
appropriate way while allowing the child to ask
questions and express viewpoints.
1 of 11 open youth case files reviewed contained 3 case contacts that did not
document that a quality contact had occurred.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim 2/24/2021, CAP Approved 3/25/2021

FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care
are placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the
Case Service Plan and the Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case
Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan to review, and I will have the opportunity to
express my disagreement with the Case
Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the report
date.
8 of 11 open youth case files reviewed were either missing required PATP
signatures, contained signatures not obtained within 30 days of the report date, or
contained undated signatures that were not uploaded within 30 days and did not
have coinciding case contacts to verify the date obtained. (16 of 33 PATPs
reviewed)
7

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Review individual policy requirements for specific upload timeframes.
• Case contacts must be entered for each contact with youth, parents, caregivers,
etc., Several documents contained signature dates with no corresponding case
contacts.
• If participating parents are being seen in person, PATPs should not indicate that
PATPs were being provided via mail, email, phone without documentation that
the PATP was discussed/reviewed with the parent.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• If theatrical films are used as foster parent training, they should only be used if
the agency has determined that the film contains education that coincides with
the training requirements. Individual training credits should be established for
each approved film along with documentation that the foster parent received
applicable training/education from the film's content.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this review
8

period. This special evaluation was reviewed and determined to have been
completed thoroughly and adequately addressed the allegations.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows.
The agency submitted one CAP which was in response to the 3/11/2022
licensing renewal inspection and was approved on 3/25/22. That CAP addressed
9 violations, 6 of which were repeated during this inspection. The three areas in
which the agency achieved and maintained CAP compliance were foster parent
first aid & CPR training, foster home licensing recommendations, and adoption
file storage. The number of violations increased to 12 this year; however, the
majority of those violations were found in 1 or 2 files. The areas with a substantial
number of incidents on violated were related to obtaining PATP signatures and
file management. It was noted that the majority of documents reviewed during
this inspection were uploaded within 2 weeks of the inspection date. At least 3
files reviewed would have contained very little documentation throughout the
year until those documents were uploaded.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment was reviewed and discussed during the
entrance conference. The chief administrator accurately identified issues with
uploading documentation timely as well as obtaining parent signatures on
documentation.
Financial Overview
A financial audit was not required as this licensee is an MDHHS office.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed reported receiving support and assistance from their
superiors and peers. Two of the staff interviewed reported a lack of awareness
that there are timeframe expectations for uploading documents into the case
record. None of that staff interviewed reported any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency appears to have sufficient office space and equipment to perform the
required job functions. The case files & CHRI records are stored securely in
cabinets that lock in a manner that prevents unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No safety concerns identified.
9

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
